text:
If I asked you to list what foods come to
mind when you think of thanksgiving dinner,
I’m positive sweet potato is on that list.

Often times candied, roasted, or in a casserole,
these root vegetables can be found alongside
the rest of the dinner assortments.

But when it comes to thanksgiving tradition
in some black communities and the state of

North Carolina specifically, the sweet in
sweet potatoes is taken a little more literally.

According to the North Carolina sweet potato
commission, sweet potatoes are as American
as apple pie.

In fact, Native Americans were recorded to
have been growing the cro[\p as far back as
the 1700s.

But there appears to be a bit of a sweet potato
gap in American history, as it only regrew
in popularity later down the line.

It was only until the crop became a western
European trend that sweet potatoes were once

again spotted in wealthy American colonial
kitchens.

Unfortunately, these kitchens included the
likes of the Big Houses located throughout
southern plantations.
But more on that in just a second.

I can’t talk about sweet potato pie without
addressing the elephant in the room, aka pumpkin
pie.

Instead of debating whether the squash or
starch reigns supreme in the already odd concept

of a vegetable-based dessert pie, why don’t
we take a look at how and why this distinction
came to be.

Cookbooks of the 1800s, often titled variations
of the “virginia, Kentucky, or Carolina”

housewife, featured a recipe very similar
to the ever-classic pumpkin pie, just with
sweet potatoes instead.

This is largely due to the fact that sweet
potatoes thrived in southern climates, while
pumpkins preferred northern.

Within the Big Houses, tasks such as cooking
and making desserts were done by enslaved
African Americans.

Within the slaves own cabins, they had root
cellars in which they stored sweet potatoes
through harsh winter months.

While the potatoes were often roasted and
“candied”, the tradition of making pies

for holidays and special occasions was only
made possible when products like processed
flour and affordable stoves were made available.

As time went on, sweet potato pie came to
be a significant part of black culture and
cuisine.

After the emancipation, the newly freed slaves
traveled to different parts of the country

and brought their love of sweet potato pie
with them, thus making it a national favorite
today.

When it comes to North Carolina specifically,
their sandy soil and climate has been ideal
for growing the crop.

It has been a vital part of the state’s
economy, with harvesting increasing significantly

when they needed to find an alternative crop
to tobacco.

And since 1971 up until now, North Carolina
has been the nation’s top producer of sweet

potatoes, even supplying nearly half of the
nation’s annual crop.

And while sweet potato pie is largely considered
to be the unofficial state dessert of North

Carolina, sweet potatoes themselves were designated
the official state vegetable by the General
Assembly of 1995.

It’s not often that you find vegetables
in your desserts, so I’ll count the daily
servings every time I can.

Speaking of dessert, what kind of pie will
you be having for thanksgiving this year?

Do you personally prefer pumpkin or sweet
potato?

And what state and what dessert do you wanna
see next?
